title: Background
text: Microbial explicit carbon models include process-based representations microbial activity soil carbon models. However, microbial-explicit models diverse terms pool structure, representations carbon flux dynamics, environmental drivers, illustrated Figure 1. variations carbon model structures dynamics contribute diverging long-term model projections, making model inter-comparisons difficult. order explore, attribute, better understand implications varying representations C dynamics, Microbial Explicit Model Consortium (MEMC) adopts uniform pool structure enable easy model comparison exercises. implementing MEMC R package, hope make soil carbon modeling accessible wider audience.

title: Background
text: MEMC uses common model structure visualized Figure 2. first version package, users ability decide implementation POM decomposition (1), DOM uptake (2), microbial biomass decay (3) indicated (Figure 3). flexible framework allows users isolate effects flux dynamics model behavior.

title: Background
text: MEMC R package ships six model pre-configured models (MICMS, MEND, CORPSE, BAMS, COMISSION, MEMS). model implementations use uniform pool structure Figure 2 use different combination C flux dynamics indicated Figure 3.

title: Background
text: MM: Michaelis Menten model, commonly used equation biogeochemical modelings describe rate reaction response change substrate. Reverse MM: Reverse Michaelis Menten model (RMM), modified version Michaelis Menten model, however now modeled reaction rate changes varies response enzyme availability. Linear: simple linear model (LM) used. Density Dependent: Density Dependent (DD) model density population (microbial biomass) affects rate given process. ECA: Equilibrium Chemistry Approximation kinetics alternative representation biogeochemical processes appropriate wide range substrate availability.

title: Change Model Parameters
text: Run pre-configured MEMC MEND model default parameter values.
code: time <- 0:600  mod1 <- MEND_config out1 <- memc_solve(mod = mod1, time = time) out1$name <- "Km = 250 (default)"

title: Change Model Parameters
text: Users can update parameters directly via memc_solve. parameter(s) value(s) fed memc_solve params argument overwrite parameter values defined model configuration.
code: out2 <- memc_solve(mod = MEND_config, time = time, params = c("K_m" = 10)) out2$name <- "Km = 10 (lower)" ggplot(data = rbind(out1, out2)) +    geom_line(aes(time, value, color = name, linetype = name), linewidth = 0.75) +    facet_wrap("variable", scales = "free") +    labs(y = "mg C/g soil",         title = "Change Km Values") +   theme(legend.title = element_blank())

title: Change Model Parameters
text: memc_update_params helper function can change parameter values parameter table. need set new model configuration new parameter table.
code: new_km <- memc_update_params(new_params = c("K_m" = 100), param_table = memc_params)  # Set up the new model configuration with the  mod_km <- memc_configure(params = new_km,                          state = memc_initial_state,                         name = "Km = 100",                          DOMuptake = "MM",                         POMdecomp = "MM",                         MBdecay = "LM")  out3 <- memc_solve(mod = mod_km, time = time) ggplot(data = rbind(out1, out2, out3)) +    geom_line(aes(time, value, color = name, linetype = name), linewidth = 0.75) +    facet_wrap("variable", scales = "free") +    labs(y = "mg C/g soil",         title = "Change Km Values") +   theme(legend.title = element_blank())

title: Fit model to data
text: Start loading comparison data, included package data. Set MIMCS model different initial pool sizes consistent experiment setup. Run model original parameter values. Use memc_modfit fit model observed data. Description inputs MEMC function memc_modfit follows: config: MEMC model configuration object, either one pre-built configurations listed memc_all_configs created using configure_config comp_data: data frame containing comparison data model fit Re run model parameter values. Plot model results vs comparison data:
code: # This assumes that the MEMC package has already been installed.  library(MEMC)  # Used to visualize results library(ggplot2)   theme_set(theme_bw() + theme(legend.title = element_blank())) comp_data <- memc_incubation_ultisol$data[c(1, 3)] names(comp_data) <- c("time", "IC") # Save a copy of the mimics model configuration.  my_mod_config <- MEMC::MIMCS_config  # Update the MEND model initial state conditions to reflect  # the experimental setup my_mod_config$state <- memc_incubation_ultisol$state original_rslts <- memc_solve(my_mod_config, time = 0:max(comp_data$time)) fit <- memc_modfit(config = my_mod_config,                     comp_data = comp_data,                     x = c(V_d = 2, V_p = 5, V_m = 0.01))  fit$par #>        V_d        V_p        V_m  #>  4.8977708 31.3576028  0.3833364 new_rslts <- memc_solve(my_mod_config, params = fit$par, time = 0:max(comp_data$time)) # Format into a single data table to plot original_rslts$par <- "original values" new_rslts$par <- "fitted values" out <- rbind(original_rslts, new_rslts) ggplot(data = out[out$variable == "IC", ]) +   geom_line(aes(time, value, color = par)) +   geom_point(data = comp_data, aes(time, IC)) +   facet_wrap("variable", scales = "free") +    labs(x = "Time (days)", y = "mg C/g soil", title = "MIMCS")

title: Install & Build
text: Follow download installation instructions R R studio. Use remotes install MEMC built R package directory github.
code: # use install.packages("remotes") to install this package the first time. library(remotes)  # Now build and install the R package on your local machine. install_github('Microbial-Explicit-Model/MEMC')   # You can also install from specific git tags... install_github("Microbial-Explicit-Model/MEMC@version")  # ...branches... install_github("Microbial-Explicit-Model/MEMC@branch_name")  # ...or commit hashes. install_github("Microbial-Explicit-Model/MEMC@commit-hash")

title: Install & Build
text: Clone repository github install package development mode. Build package calling devtools::load_all() R root directory. Please see r-pkgs information build develop R packages. making changes code, checking new git branch, pulling new commits need clean rebuild MEMC package. Rstudio click Build > Clean Rebuild run following R console.
code: devtools::build()

title: MEMC
text: package ships several already defined model configurations; use help(configurations) see list. Currently six configurations included internal MEMC package data, using different representations DOM uptake, POM decomposition, MB decay. MEMC model configurations listed memc_all_configs listed summary table. Let’s try using MEND, microbial enzyme-mediated decomposition model originally developed Wang et al. 2014. can type help("MEND_config") details pre-built configuration. Perform model run using memc_solve function, whose inputs : mod. MEMC model object, either one model configurations included package created using memc_configure(); times. numeric vector time sequence model solved; first value times initial time. model run results saved mend_out data frame. Visualize run results:

title: Microbial Explicit Model Comparison
text: MEMC R package allows users explore various representation soil organic matter (SOM) flux dynamics within consistent SOM model structure. Popular microbial-explicit SOM models MEND1, MIMICS2, CORPSE3 vary significantly formulations microbial mechanisms underlying pool structure. MEMC provides consistent pool structure flexible flux dynamics: conceptual mathematical formulations key SOC tranformations can rapidly changed. allows modelers easily explore effects different conceptualizations microbial mechanisms.

title: Microbial Explicit Model Comparison
text: Follow download installation instructions R R studio. Use remotes install MEMC built R package directory GitHub. Now load MEMC package:
code: # use install.packages("remotes") to install this package the first time. library(remotes)  # Now build and install the R package on your local machine. install_github('Microbial-Explicit-Model/MEMC') library(MEMC)

title: Configurations — configurations
text: various model configurations shipped MEMC package, : BAMS_config, COMISSION_config, CORPSE_config, MEND_config, MIMCS_config, MEMS_config. supported model configurations listed memc_all_configs.

title: Configurations — configurations
text: model configurations can used memc_solve function complete desired model simulations.

title: Configurations — configurations
code: ## Using memc_solve with the MEND_config configuration. out <- memc_solve(mod = MEND_config, time = 0:10)

what: MEMC supported SOM flux dynamics — dynamics
title: MEMC supported SOM flux dynamics — dynamics
text: identifiers correspond various dynamics users can select setting model configuration using memc_configure function.

title: MEMC supported SOM flux dynamics — dynamics
text: MM Michaelis–Menten kinetics RMM Reverse Michaelis-Menten kinetics, (Schimel Weintraub, 2003) (Sulman et al. 2014) ECA Equilibrium Chemistry Approximation, based RESOM (Tang Riley, 2014) DD Density Dependent decomposition (applicable MB decay) LM Linear odel, (Robertson et al. 2019)

title: MEMC supported SOM flux dynamics — dynamics
text: Schimel, J. P., M. N. Weintraub (2003), implications exoenzyme activity microbial carbon nitrogen limitation soil: theoretical model, Soil Biol. Biochem., 35(4), 549–563, doi:10.1016/s0038-0717(03)00015-4 Sulman, B. N., R. P. Phillips, . C. Oishi, E. Shevliakova, S. W. Pacala (2014), Microbe-driven turnover offsets mineral-mediated storage soil carbon elevated CO2, Nat. Clim. Change, 4(12), 1099–1102, doi:10.1038/nclimate2436. Tang, J., Riley, W. Weaker soil carbon–climate feedbacks resulting microbial abiotic interactions. Nature Clim Change 5, 56–60 (2015). https://doi.org/10.1038/nclimate2438 Robertson, . D., Paustian, K., Ogle, S., Wallenstein, M. D., Lugato, E., Cotrufo, M. F.: Unifying soil organic matter formation persistence frameworks: MEMS model, Biogeosciences, 16, 1225–1248, https://doi.org/10.5194/bg-16-1225-2019, 2019.

title: Flexible SOM fluxes — fluxes
text: Description flexible SOM fluxes users may change memc_configure function.

title: Flexible SOM fluxes — fluxes
text: DOMuptake dissolved organic uptake microbial biomass, flux describing DOM broken microbial biomoass uptake. POMdecomp particulate oranic matter decomposition, flux describing POM broken DOM. MBdecay microbial biomass decay, flux descirbing micorbial biomass mortality/turn .

title: Global sensitivity ranges for a MEMC model — memc_sensrange
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Test the sensitivity of the MEND output for V_p, K_p, V_m pars <- c("V_d" = 3.0e+00,"V_p" = 1.4e+01,"V_m" = 2.5e-01) prange <- data.frame(min = pars - pars * 0.75, max = pars + pars * 0.75) t <- floor(seq(0, 365, length.out = 10)) out <- memc_sensrange(config = MEND_config, t = t, x = pars, parRange = prange, dist = "latin", num = 10) plot(out) } # }

title: Example data from Sulman et al. (2018) — sulman2018

title: Example data from Sulman et al. (2018) — sulman2018
code: # Access the data sulman2018 #> # A tibble: 48,042 × 7 #>    model  clay   litter      experiment month name                 value #>    <chr>  <chr>  <chr>       <chr>      <dbl> <chr>                <dbl> #>  1 CORPSE medium highquality control        0 total_protectedC   5.10    #>  2 CORPSE medium highquality control        0 total_unprotectedC 0.378   #>  3 CORPSE medium highquality control        0 total_C            5.50    #>  4 CORPSE medium highquality control        0 total_microbeC     0.0234  #>  5 CORPSE medium highquality control        0 total_litterC      0       #>  6 CORPSE medium highquality control        0 CO2flux            0.00136 #>  7 CORPSE medium highquality control        1 total_protectedC   5.10    #>  8 CORPSE medium highquality control        1 total_unprotectedC 0.378   #>  9 CORPSE medium highquality control        1 total_C            5.50    #> 10 CORPSE medium highquality control        1 total_microbeC     0.0233  #> # ℹ 48,032 more rows  # Reconstruct figure 3 from Sulman et al. (2018) # For this, we need to combine control and treatment data... x <- subset(sulman2018, experiment == "total_addition_100") x_control <- subset(sulman2018, experiment == "control") names(x_control)[names(x_control) == "value"] <- "control_value" x_control$experiment <- NULL dat <- merge(x, x_control) # ... and compute the log response ratio dat$log_response <- log(dat$value) - log(dat$control_value) library(ggplot2) ggplot(dat, aes(month, log_response, color = model)) +  geom_line() + facet_wrap(~name, scales = "free") +  scale_color_manual(values = c("CORPSE" = "blue", "MEND" = "red", "MIMICS" = "purple"))
